advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPAN ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>It's an advert for both the YIS-503 and YIS-303 which were quite similar except for the keyboard and the memory size...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - SYSTEM IN SPACE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://pcenginefx.com" target="_blank">PC-EngineFX.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #16</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Each day, go on the computing road''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR CARDS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Northstar also designed cards for S100 Bus. These cards were used in the Horizon and were also available separately for competing systems.<br> Cards on the photo are:<br> - 16 KB RAM board ($459 assembled)<br> - Micro Disk System (card & interface) to connect Shugart FDD ($799)<br> - Z80A processor board ($259 without EPROM option, $330 with)<br> - Hardware floating point card ($359). </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARGENTINIAN ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.speccy.org/czarg/" target="_blank">CZARG</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>English advert for the 86A model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It has not finished to surprise you"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: only machine code entered through the hexadecimal keyboard
computer.description:
The SuperElf single-board computer was made by Quest Electronics. It was an improvement of the Netronics Elf and Elf II training boards, also based on the RCA 1802, one of the first RISC microprocessors.
The board also featured an 1861 video chip that was closely tied ot the 1802 to generate a video image of 128x64 dots.
Two, four or six 7-segment Led display could be used. Its hexadecimal keyboard allowed programs to be entered and controlled more efficiently thanks to 8 function keys: I - Input L - Load mode R - Reset G - Go (run mode) W - Wait (processor clock could be stopped) M - enable Monitor ROM S - Single step P - Protect memory
The main board had connections for a speaker (and a circuit to drive the speaker). Sound was entirely software driven as the hardware simply had a single digital output bit (Q) tied to an LED and also to the speaker.
An optional expansion board could be added, providing serial port (software driven), cassette interface (also software driven), 1 KB ROM monitor, optional 2K tiny basic, 4 KB RAM. 2 S-100 slots where additional static memory or a video board could be used. Along with a Super Monitor, there where two versions of pitman's tiny basic, one that used the 1861 video chip and another that used a 64 characters x16lines s-100 video board.
The cassette's output used the same 'Q' output used for audio on the main board, which meant that you heard all of your data as it was written out to cassette.
The 9 LEDs along the left side of the keypad indicate the state of the 'Q' output, the current operating mode (Load, Reset, Run, Wait) as well as the current state of the CPU (Fetch, Execute, DMA, Interrupt).

emulator.description: Emulation of 1802-based computer now on Mac OS X
emulator.name: TinyELF for MacOS

emulator.description: Elf, Elf II, Super ELF and Studio II emulator (Windows compilation also available)
emulator.name: RCS Elf Emulator

emulator.description: Emulates an Elf computer on PalmOS systems. The Elf is quite similar to the Cosmac VIP.
emulator.name: TinyELF for PalmOS

computer.language: only machine code entered through the hexadecimal keyboard
computer.name: SuperElf
computer.ports: External power transformer, optional expansion connector

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> STANDARD QUEST WOODEN BOX</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.elf-emulation.com" target="_blank">www.elf-emulation.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> METAL BOX</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Mike Riley</b> from <a href="http://www.elf-emulation.com" target="_blank">www.elf-emulation.com</a> relates : <br><br> ''I was told that this case is one of a kind, Quest only sold the expanded metal cases and never went beyond the prototype with this basic metal case''<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.elf-emulation.com" target="_blank">www.elf-emulation.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.sound: speaker hooked to Q output - shared with Q LED. (Twiddle Q output at a fixed frequency - get that frequency out)
computer.text: 2 to 6 7-segment Led display (on all the time)
